Title: Enhanced Recovery After Surgery Protocols in Total Joint Replacement: A Randomised Controlled Trial

Background: Enhanced recovery after surgery (ERAS) protocols aim to improve patient outcomes through comprehensive perioperative strategies. This study evaluates the application of ERAS protocols in total joint replacement (TJR) surgery.

Methods: This randomised controlled trial was conducted at a tertiary care hospital. Participants were adults undergoing TJR, with eligibility criteria including age 18-75 and ASA physical status I-III. The intervention group received ERAS protocols, while the control group received standard care. The primary outcome was hospital length of stay (LOS), measured over a 30-day postoperative period. Randomisation was computer-generated, with allocation concealment via sealed envelopes. Blinding was applied to outcome assessors.

Results: A total of 200 participants were randomised: 100 to the ERAS group and 100 to the control group, between January 2020 and June 2021. Analysis included 98 participants in the ERAS group and 97 in the control group, using an intention-to-treat approach. The ERAS group had a significantly reduced LOS (mean difference = 1.5 days, 95% CI 1.0 to 2.0; p < 0.001). Adverse events were reported in 3% of the ERAS group and 1% of the control group, with mild gastrointestinal side-effects.

Interpretation: ERAS protocols significantly reduce hospital LOS in TJR patients without increasing adverse events. Trial registration: NCT01234567. Funding: Supported by the National Institutes of Health.
